methods: carotid femoral pulse wave velocity measurement

resistance training models.reasoning: Resistance training models refer to the specific types of training programs being compared in the study, which is a methodological approach to understand their effects on arterial stiffness.
passages: to determine the effect of 2 resistance training models on indices of arterial stiffness in young, healthy women

randomization.reasoning: Randomization is a method used to assign subjects to different groups in a way that minimizes bias, ensuring the validity of the experimental results.
passages: Twenty-four women, untrained college students, aged 18-22 years were randomized into 1 of 3 groups

exercise regimen.reasoning: The exercise regimen describes the specific protocol that participants followed during the study, outlining the frequency and structure of the training sessions.
passages: Subjects randomized to resistance training groups were required to perform strength training exercises 3-5 days a week for 11 weeks.

strength training exercises.reasoning: Strength training exercises are the specific activities performed by participants, which are central to the intervention being studied.
passages: The exercise regimen consisted of 2-3 sets of 3-8 repetitions (80-90% of 1 repetition maximum [1RM]) for the HI group and 3-4 sets of 10-15 repetitions (50-70% of 1RM) for the HV group.

carotid femoral pulse wave velocity meas.reasoning: This measurement technique is used to assess arterial stiffness, which is a key outcome variable in the study, representing a specific methodological approach.
passages: there was a significant increase in carotid femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV)

maximum squat assessment.reasoning: Maximum squat assessment refers to the specific test used to evaluate strength improvements in participants, serving as a measure of the effectiveness of the training.
passages: Both the HI and HV groups increased their maximum squat

bench press assessment.reasoning: Bench press assessment is another specific strength test used in the study to measure the effectiveness of the resistance training programs.
passages: bench press (34.4 +/- 12.6 vs. 23.4 +/- 11.1 percent change; p < 0.05)

seated row assessment.reasoning: Seated row assessment is yet another specific strength test that was conducted to evaluate participant performance as part of the study's methodology.
passages: seated row (22.0 +/- 12.6 vs. 21.9 +/- 12.5 percent change; p < 0.05)
